Award.AwardTitle: Measuring Collaboration in Complex Computerized Performance Assessments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ECR program of fundamental research in STEM education provides funding in critical research areas that are essential, broad and enduring. EHR seeks proposals that will help synthesize, build and/or expand research foundations in the following focal areas: STEM learning, STEM learning environments, STEM workforce development, and broadening participation in STEM. The ECR program is distinguished by its emphasis on the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to (a) understand, (b) build theory to explain, and (c) suggest interventions (and innovations) to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning, and participation. The motivational context for this project is that nearly all definitions of 21st century skills include some aspects of collaborative problem solving. Often the skills associated with such collaborations are treated separately. In this study the researchers will investigate these collaborative problem solving skills interactively. The research team will draw on process data automatically generated as students work in the virtual environments that support the learning of circuit design and electronics.

The technical aspects of this research will use data mining techniques and expert judgment to validate the inferences of the PI team. In addition the project will engage two critically related components: (1) the development of a generalizable schema that will measure student content and collaborative problem solving (CPS) skills in computerized educational environments, and (2) the construction and validation of diagnostic student profiles generated by the schema.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative problem solving (CPS) has been identified as one of the most important skills for the 21st century workforce; however, only recently has research begun to focus to a greater extent on measuring CPS skills. The complexity of CPS requires appropriate methods for synthesizing large amounts of data to make inferences about individuals and how they function within teams. The goal of this project was to develop a conceptual framework to support measurement of complex constructs in digital environments and apply the framework to measure individuals? CPS skills during engagement in a simulation-based task. We developed the In-Task Assessment Framework (I-TAF), an extension of evidence-centered design (ECD), which reconceptualizes what it means to define a construct of interest, extract evidence of learner performance, and link the evidence back to the construct when evidence is tied to fine-grained log data (e.g., mouse clicks) rather than standard item response data (e.g., multiple choice questions).

We implemented I-TAF to develop a comprehensive competency model of CPS in the form of an ontology (similar to a concept map). The top portion of the ontology provides a generalizable construct definition of CPS (e.g., sharing information as one skill of CPS) that can be utilized in other work seeking to measure CPS or other related constructs. The lower levels of the ontology provide more specificity, describing CPS within a domain (e.g., sharing status updates) and then within the specific task context being used (e.g., sharing the status of resistance in a circuit). Links between the layers in the ontology describe how behaviors at lower levels of the ontology can be combined to make inferences about high-level behaviors. High-level skills in the ontology are divided into social (maintaining communication, establishing shared understanding, sharing information, negotiating) and cognitive (exploring and understanding, representing and formulating, planning, executing, monitoring) dimensions. The ontology was developed based on an extensive literature review and then iteratively refined based on empirical evidence across two data collections. The full CPS ontology can be found here.

After creating the CPS competency model, we modified a collaborative simulation-based task on electronics concepts called the Three-Resistor Activity. These modifications were aimed to include affordances that provide opportunities for students to display the targeted CPS skills. For the task, undergraduate students worked in groups of three, each on a separate computer, and each running a simulation of a portion of an electronics circuit. Across four task levels of increasing difficulty, teams had the goal of working together to reach a specified goal voltage across each student?s resistor.

For analyses, we first implemented a theoretically-grounded data mining approach in which the CPS competency model guided feature selection and educational data mining techniques were used to create student CPS skill profiles. Across two data sets we identified six different types of collaborative problem solvers that were defensible with respect to theoretical interpretations: Active Collaborators, Social Loafers, Group Organizers, Chatty Doers, Super Socials, and Low Collaborators. Details of this work can be found here and here. In a second approach to creating profiles, students were grouped based on frequencies with which they displayed social relative to cognitive CPS behaviors (i.e., high social/high cognitive, high social/low cognitive, low social/high cognitive, low social/low cognitive). In support of validating profiles, all profiles showed relationships with external measures (e.g., electronics content knowledge, task performance, self-reported CPS skills) in expected directions. We further conducted exploratory analyses to examine how network analyses could be used to understand connections among individuals? CPS behaviors. We found that CPS skill networks for teams completing more task levels were better connected and had more coverage than did teams completing fewer task levels. Details of this work can be found here.

The principled assessment methodology developed in this project (I-TAF) can inform and shape the ways in which assessment developers and researchers build digital performance assessments and make sense of the data from those assessments. In the context of CPS, the approach provides a CPS competency model that can be modified for others? purposes, a process for extracting features associated with the competency model from fine-grained log data, and methodologies for aggregating the information to make inferences about individuals.
